p._value:
openssl-enc,
enc - symmetric cipher routines

The symmetric
cipher commands allow data to be encrypted or decrypted
using various block and stream ciphers using keys based on
passwords or explicitly provided. Base64 encoding or
decoding can also be performed either by itself or in
addition to the encryption or decryption.
Print out a usage message.
List all supported ciphers.

Alias of -list to display all
supported ciphers.

The input filename, standard
input by default.

The output filename, standard
output by default.

_values:
The password source. For more
information about the format of

see "Pass
Phrase Options" in

p._value:
Use the specified digest to
create the key from the passphrase. The default algorithm is
sha-256.

_values:
Use a given number of
iterations on the password in deriving the encryption key.
High values increase the time required to brute-force the
resulting file. This option enables the use of
algorithm to derive the key.
Use

algorithm with default iteration count unless otherwise
specified.

Don’t use a salt in the
key derivation routines. This option

be used except for test purposes or
compatibility with ancient versions of OpenSSL.

Use salt (randomly generated or
provide with

option) when encrypting, this is the
default.

The actual salt to use: this
must be represented as a string of hex digits.

_values:

must be represented as a string comprised only of hex

must additionally specified using the

option.
When both a key and a password are specified, the key given
with the
option will be used and the

generated from the password will be taken.
It does not make much sense to specify both key and
password.

to

must explicitly be

cipher
(no encryption or decryption of input).

A file or files containing
random data used to seed the random number generator.
Multiple files can be specified separated by an OS-dependent
character. The separator is
for MS-Windows,
for OpenVMS, and
for all others.

Writes random data to the
specified

upon exit. This can be used with a

The program can
be called either as
or

. The first form doesn’t work with
engine-provided ciphers, because this form is processed
before the configuration file is read and any ENGINEs
loaded. Use the

command to get a list of
supported ciphers.

p._value:
Engines which
provide entirely new encryption algorithms (such as the
ccgost engine which provides gost89 algorithm) should be
configured in the configuration file. Engines specified on
the command line using -engine options can only be used for
hardware-assisted implementations of ciphers which are
supported by the OpenSSL core or another engine specified in
the configuration file.

When the enc
command lists supported ciphers, ciphers provided by
engines, specified in the configuration files are listed
too.

_values:
A password will
be prompted for to derive the key and

if
necessary.
The
option should

be
used if the key is being derived from a password unless you
want compatibility with previous versions of OpenSSL.
Without the

option it is possible to perform efficient
dictionary attacks on the password and to attack stream
cipher encrypted data. The reason for this is that without
the salt the same password always generates the same
encryption key. When the salt is being used the first eight
bytes of the encrypted data are reserved for the salt: it is
generated at random when encrypting a file and read from the
encrypted file when it is decrypted.

Some of the
ciphers do not have large keys and others have security
implications if not used correctly. A beginner is advised to
just use a strong block cipher, such as
in
mode.

p._value:
All the block
ciphers normally use PKCS#5 padding, also known as standard
block padding. This allows a rudimentary integrity or
password check to be performed. However, since the chance of
random data passing the test is better than 1 in 256 it
isn’t a very good test.

If padding is
disabled then the input data must be a multiple of the
cipher block length.

_values: All

ciphers have the same key and effective
key length.
Blowfish and
algorithms use a 128 bit key.

Note that some
of these ciphers can be disabled at compile time and some
are available only if an appropriate engine is configured in
the configuration file. The output of the

command
run with the
option (that is
The
program does not support authenticated encryption modes like
and

and will not
support such modes in the future. The

interface
by necessity must begin streaming output (e.g., to standard
output when

is not used) before the
authentication tag could be validated, leading to the usage
of

in pipelines that begin processing untrusted
data and are not capable of rolling back upon authentication
failure. The

modes currently in common
use also suffer from catastrophic failure of confidentiality
and/or integrity upon reuse of key/iv/nonce, and since

places the entire burden of key/iv/nonce
management upon the user, the risk of exposing

modes is too great to allow. These
key/iv/nonce management issues also affect other modes
currently exposed in

, but the failure modes are
less extreme in these cases, and the functionality cannot be
removed with a stable release branch. For bulk encryption of
data, whether using authenticated encryption modes or other
modes,

(1) is recommended, as it provides a
standard data format and performs the needed key/iv/nonce
management.

p._value:
Just base64
encode a binary file:

openssl base64
-in file.bin -out file.b64

Decode the same
file

openssl base64
-d -in file.b64 -out file.bin

_values:
Encrypt a file
using
using a prompted password and
key derivation:

p._value:
openssl enc
-aes128 -pbkdf2 -in file.txt -out file.aes128

Decrypt a file
using a supplied password:

_values:
openssl enc
-aes128 -pbkdf2 -d -in file.aes128 -out file.txt \
-pass pass:<password>

Encrypt a file
then base64 encode it (so it can be sent via mail for
example) using
in
mode and
key derivation:

p._value:
openssl enc
-aes-256-ctr -pbkdf2 -a -in file.txt -out file.aes256

Base64 decode a
file then decrypt it using a password supplied in a
file:

_values:
openssl enc
-aes-256-ctr -pbkdf2 -d -a -in file.aes256 -out file.txt \
-pass file:<passfile>
The

option when used with large files doesn’t work
properly.
The

program only supports a fixed number of algorithms with
certain parameters. So if, for example, you want to use
with a 76 bit key or
with an 84 bit key you can’t use this program.

The default
digest was changed from
to
in OpenSSL 1.1.0.
The
option was added in OpenSSL 1.1.1e.

p._value: Encrypt the input data: this is the default.
Decrypt the input data.

Base64 process the data. This means that if encryption
is taking place the data is base64 encoded after encryption.
If decryption is set then the input data is base64 decoded
before being decrypted.

_values: If the

option is set then base64 process the
data on one line.
Print out the key and
used.
Print out the key and

used then
immediately exit: don’t do any encryption or
decryption.

p._value:
Compress or decompress encrypted data using zlib after
encryption or before decryption. This option exists only if
OpenSSL was compiled with the zlib or zlib-dynamic
option.
